title: Please tell me that's not all you're going to give Veigar after trashing him.
body:
Sure the current buffs are nice, and take time to think of. Hell, I think he'll be better too.

But please, for the love of all that is holy, do not think that he'll be 100% after those buffs. He'll still need something more. I saw meddler say something about shortening the W's impact delay, but no changes were made to it...

So please, take it into consideration.

When making changes to champs like veig and cass, riot really neglected to get the players opinion on **why** they enjoy the champ and what direction they want the champ to go in. I understand each champ had balance issues, and some changes may have been necessary to some degree. But that is besides the point.

With cass, riot fundamentally altered her core gameplay focus by changing her from a zone control/siege mage that melts opponents with powerful dots to a dps berserker that focused on mowing down targets one after the other. Their core argument for nerfing her poisons was that she was too strong of a lane bully that scaled too well into the late game. My response is simple: If her late game scaling is too strong, nerf the AP ratio on her E. That would allow her to retain her lane bullying power without becoming an insane monster late game. But instead they did the reverse.

Now riot is doing something similar with veigar. They are removing one of the core reasons players picked him (his reliability) and dangerously shifting his playstyle from his iconic **single-target** burst mage to a poorly done zone control poke mage. Number buffs are pointless atm because the core issue isn't about numbers and dmg, it's about play style.

> With cass, riot fundamentally altered her core gameplay focus by changing her from a zone control/siege mage that melts opponents with powerful dots to a dps berserker that focused on mowing down targets one after the other. 

Old Cass was just as much about eye popping E damage as she was about DoTs.

> Their core argument for nerfing her poisons was that she was too strong of a lane bully that scaled too well into the late game. 

If Cass was just too strong at all points in the game, nerfing would have been easy.  The problem was that Old Cass was an oppressive laner that ended up having no point in the late game.  The need to simultaneously add counterplay to her laning and also buff her lategame is what make the rework such a challenge.

> My response is simple: If her late game scaling is too strong, nerf the AP ratio on her E. 

There was a way to make the poison mage players of Cass happy.  The problem is that it would make the other side of the playerbase unhappy.

> Now riot is doing something similar with veigar. They are removing one of the core reasons players picked him (his reliability) and dangerously shifting his playstyle from his iconic single-target burst mage to a poorly done zone control poke mage. Number buffs are pointless atm because the core issue isn't about numbers and dmg, it's about play style.

Reliable single target burst damage is not good for the game.  I know Veigar players liked that.  Doesn't matter.  Can't support that fantasy in a competitive game.

> If Cass was just too strong at all points in the game, nerfing would have been easy. The problem was that Old Cass was an oppressive laner that ended up having no point in the late game. The need to simultaneously add counterplay to her laning and also buff her lategame is what make the rework such a challenge.

I think you fail to comprehend the whole point of the role "lane bully."

That is the sole reason you *pick* lane bullies is to try to shut down a dangerous lane opponent in the hopes that your team can take advantage of that. You do the heavy lifting in the early game so that your team can close the deal instead of waiting out till the late game and do your hard carrying then. A great example of a lane bully that was extremely popular in the past was renekton.

The reason lane bullies can be bad for game health is IF they *do* have a strong late game, that is when they become over bearing and a game health problem. Falling off in dmg late game is a cost they take for having such a successful laning phase. And I feel that due to the lack of lane bullies assassins are having a heyday with it. (that, and zed's laning phase is way too safe/easy)

> Reliable single target burst damage is not good for the game. I know Veigar players liked that. Doesn't matter. Can't support that fantasy in a competitive game.

I strongly disagree. I fully believe a single-target burst play style can not only be healthy for league, but that the distinct lack of such champs is actually hurting league in the long run.

Having a champ dedicated to deleting one target causes players to actually think out what they are doing rather than blindly jumping into a fight and hoping they land their stuff before jumping out again. It also adds to the importance of positioning both before and during team fights by forcing players to realize that their dashes and flashes won't always save them from being stupidly out of place.

I find the distinct *lack* of inevitability causes players to forget about planning and the importance of each choice they make over the course of the game can have a lasting impact on how the rest of the game plays out.

Veigar in particular did this well. If you let him farm in lane without mercilessly crushing him, he *will* turn the tables on you. Veigar's theme is about certain demise and unrelenting revenge. And that translated well with his reliable kit. He created a "death zone" around him that all but the tankiest of champs should be scared silly to approach.

That being said, Veigar was far from being a "broken" champ. I've had numerous games where I was so fed, I had more gold than I knew what to do with, but despite it all, I could not win the game simply because after 40-50 min into the game, there are just *too many* enemies that need to be killed. And I can only kill so many of them within a certain time period. It didn't matter if I could do 3k burst dmg to a single target if they all had more than 2.5k hp and 100 MR. It's even worse when they all buy both a banshee's and a GA which completely negates my usefulness until my team can burn through their special defenses.

There are numerous ways to over come single target burst champs, and I believe that over the years, riot has slowly been taking away the need to use these methods in favor of reactive plays and such.

You want the game to be about planning, thoughtful action, and strategic counterplay.  My advice: play DotA.  Your point of view on how things should work is considerably more aligned with that game's philosophy than this one.  

Having high burst damage is fine.  The problem is that his play pattern is too reliable for League to accommodate.  Veigar's E doesn't fit in the game.

In this game, we don't have the tools to provide strategic counterplay against reliable play patterns.  No BKB.  No Orchid.  No smoke.  No hard counter lanes.  Counterplay in League is about outplaying the opponent tactically or mechanically.

why does league have to be "either or"? That is the biggest problem with the ever growing rift in the player base atm.

Older players, such as myself, came to love league for many reasons, and it pains us to see league drift away from core gameplay styles that we grew to love about it. But at the same time, not all the change has been bad.

The problem here, is that league is swinging from one extreme to the other. We are losing one form of rich gameplay in exchange for another.

When I first started league, it was great. Was it perfect? Heck no! I've stuck with league for 5 years now and love it. Is it perfect? Heck no! The difference is 5 years ago, league was as you said "about strategic counterplay and thoughtful action." Now it has shifted to twitch plays and reactive mechanics. Neither of these are inherently bad. But the community is currently splitting apart and taking sides over which they want league to be.

See the issue?

What I'm trying to say, however, is that either one is only part of what league is. League isn't JUST reactive "LCS BIG PLAYS" nor is it JUST "thoughtful action and strategic counterplay." It's **both**.

And the sooner riot and the community realizes this, the sooner league can become a richer, fuller game for it. Simply picking sides will not make league a richer, fuller game, it will merely cause the community to self destruct and possibly cause a mass exodus to a competitor. None of which is, nor should, be a desirable outcome.

I fully believe that merging the two styles into one cohesive game is possible, it will take a lot of effort, yes, but it is not impossible.
I agree with everything you said, and upvoting it wasn't enough.  Thank you for this well expressed, well thought out comment.

Bro, Bro, Bro, tons of people have reliable single target burst, and aoe burst, veigars only preblem was his e and it really was a tiny problem with the existance of zhonyas and qss

{{champion:107}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:91}} {{champion:121}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:5}} {{champion:103}}

> veigars only preblem was his e and it really was a tiny problem with the existance of zhonyas and qss

E is indeed the problem with Old Veigar.  That's what makes his play pattern reliable -- without it, he doesn't have any safe way to close and land the rest of his stuff.

" without it, he doesn't have any safe way to close and land the rest of his stuff."

Which makes the current veigar helpless to defend himself and impotent in attacking.

Honestly, I really have listened to your argument, and I do understand your view. I would love if veigars E got reworked to something more like a xerath stun that erupts into a cage (after a delay,of course). And veigars old E was broken, possibly beyond repair. 
But you say burst is gone? Ahri is still very much real. Vi has her point and click CC that can only be stopped through items or spell sheilds. And then there is Zed. He has plenty of burst and shows it often. As well as then jumping around. LeBlanc is back with her burst, destroying Adc in a second or less. Most poke/sustained damage mages are gone now. Ziggs and Xerath are pretty much the only ones left. I get people like seeing the flashy plays, but Xerath is not flashy. He is the opposite. And they like him where he is. He can also burst people from 3/4 health with good skill shots.
Tldr; Veigar needed something done to his E. But the delay was a lazy answer.  There are lots of burst laners still around that riot has no intention of "fixing"

Not burst.  Burst is probably bigger than ever; certainly things aren't as tanky as they were in season 2.  Reliable burst is gone.

The thing where Ahri could DFG your face, then R and W to make the kill without ever landing a skillshot is gone.  The thing where LeBlanc and Talon had targeted silences that stopped you from fighting back against their burst is gone.  Rengar is still a thing, but Rengar's targeted snare and triple Q are both gone.  Burst now comes with twitch counterplay in approximately all cases.

I think Xerath has some really cool playmaking potential.  The new ult has lots of tension to it.  The way you can use new W to setup new E is sweet.  I really like this kit now...but the reliable RRR burst from the old kit is gone.

I do think that Veigar's changes were half baked.  I really like this new thing where the cage will block dashes.  That's pretty awesome.  I want W to become more of a standalone button, rather than only being good when someone gets hit with E.

Well my point about Zed still stands. His burst is very much point and click. It is also only countered by items or a few champ abilities. Not twitch reflexes.

However, anyone that argues that Veigar's old E was healthy is crazy. We can agree on that it needed to go. If they want to make Veigar good for twitch based reflexes, here are two things I see could work.
Stun delay down to .25 seconds. At the moment, it is not a twitch based counterplay so much as it is a  "slowly walk out" counterplay. Make people need to flash or jump to avoid the stun.  Obviously the stun duration would have to go down though. 
The other would be to buff his W, remove the stun from E, but Make it instant again. While keeping champs locked inside if they jump, it would be interesting to see them dash around the inside of the cage in order to avoid meteors and His q. That would be a cool change, but then its like a Jarvan ult. 
The .75 second delay is just a time saver. Its not even good in team fights, really. 
The point in trying to make is that they could keep Veigars core idea and change his stun, but they didn't. And the fact that they didn't is really just laziness. Changing his stun takes work. Making it happen later does not.

Only the R itself is guaranteed.  Everything else in his combo is avoidable -- difficult to avoid, but avoidable.  Then you have items, summoners, and champion abilities to work with, even if you fail to dodge the Q.

Zed has tons of counterplay.  What he doesn't have is any hard counters.  There's no champion you can go "ok, I picked X, so now Zed will lose lane for sure".  You have to outplay him to win.  However, the flip side of this is that you can beat Zed with dang near anything in mid.

> Stun delay down to .25 seconds. At the moment, it is not a twitch based counterplay so much as it is a  "slowly walk out" counterplay. Make people need to flash or jump to avoid the stun.  Obviously the stun duration would have to go down though. 

Certainly the timing can be adjusted. They seem to have gone overboard on the delay part -- 0.25 seconds cast, 0.5 seconds particle.  I think we should try instant cast E, with the 0.5 seconds particle delay.

I do worry that the skill is going to push league of mobility even harder.

> The other would be to buff his W, remove the stun from E, but Make it instant again. While keeping champs locked inside if they jump, it would be interesting to see them dash around the inside of the cage in order to avoid meteors and His q.
